Italian: mi chiama*ti chiama*La/lo/la chiama*ci chiama*vi chiama*li/le chiama

English: to rediscover, to find, to meet
to try to, to look for
Could you give me your pen?
Italian: Mi potresti dare la tua penna?

English: could you speak a little slower
to strike dead, to go out

Italian: to keep quiet, to fall silent

English: to be wrong, to make a mistake
of the air, of the mood
He is nicer than he is intelligent
Italian: Lui è più simpatico che intelligente

English: to be heading, to be steering

Italian: Si chiama Pietro e torna indietro

English: To not be disgusted by anything
to let go, to let out
to mean (i.e. what does that word mean?)
Would you give me your pen?
to deal, to treat, to process, to handle
to preside over, to be in charge
Someone doing something intellectual without a clue what they're doing (slang)
According to Sarah, I should have studied more
Italian: Secondo Sarah, io avrei dovuto studiare di piu

English: to call oneself (i.e. my name is)
to make your way through the crowd

Italian: in qualsiasi momento, ogni volta che

English: Someone who can convince you of anything
heart (i.e. I believe with all my heart)

Italian: Giovanni è più alto di Marco
Vai a farti benedire / Vai a quel paese

English: to be used to, accustomed to

Italian: Hai voluto la bicicletta? E adesso pedala!

English: They will leave in a month
To make a fool of oneself

Italian: ricevuto come un cane in chiesa

English: to move away, to push out
to last (i.e. how long does it last?)
to omit, to fail, to neglect
They are going to leave in a week
to let, allow, to leave something
to mean (i.e. I meant to say)
to cause, to give rise to, to produce
to find it hard, to have difficulty
to accept, to admit, to take in

Italian: In bocca al lupo, crepi il lupo

English: to succeed, to manage (i.e. he managed to smile)
